[[File:00595309(Andropov&Jaruzelski).jpeg|thumb|left|275px|General [[Wojciech Jaruzelski]] meeting [[Yuri Andropov]], the Soviet security chief, during the 1980 crisis. Jaruzelski was about to become the (last) leader of communist Poland.]]
The discontent underlying the strikes was intensified by revelations of widespread corruption and mismanagement within the Polish state and party leadership. In September 1980, Gierek was replaced by [[Stanisław Kania]] as First Secretary.
Alarmed by the rapid deterioration of the [[Polish United Workers' Party|Party]]'s authority following the Gdańsk agreement, the Soviet Union proceeded with a massive military buildup along Poland's border in December 1980. In February 1981, Defense Minister Gen. [[Wojciech Jaruzelski]] assumed the position of Prime Minister, and in October 1981, was named First Secretary. At the [[History of Solidarity|first Solidarity national congress]] in September–October 1981, Lech Wałęsa was elected national chairman of the union.
On December 12–13, the regime declared [[martial law in Poland|martial law]], under which the army and [[ZOMO]] riot police were used to crush the union. Virtually all Solidarity leaders and many affiliated intellectuals were arrested or detained. The United States and other Western countries responded to martial law by imposing economic sanctions against the Polish regime and against the Soviet Union. Unrest in Poland continued for several years thereafter.<ref name="Poland under Communism 325-331"/>
[[File:Pope John Paul II 11 06 1987 01.jpg|thumb|right|315 px|[[Pope John Paul II]] in Poland in 1987]]
Having achieved some semblance of stability, the Polish regime in several stages relaxed and then rescinded martial law. By December 1982, martial law was suspended, and a small number of political prisoners, including Wałęsa, were released. Although martial law formally ended in July 1983 and a partial amnesty was enacted, several hundred political prisoners remained in jail.<ref name="Poland under Communism 325-331"/><ref name="Poland under Communism 336-348"/>
In September 1986, general amnesty was declared and the government released nearly all political prisoners. Throughout the period the authorities continued to harass dissidents and Solidarity activists. Solidarity remained proscribed and its publications banned; independent publications were censored. However, with the economic crisis unresolved and societal institutions dysfunctional, both the ruling establishment and Solidarity-led opposition began looking for ways out of the stalemate, and exploratory contacts were being established.<ref name="Poland under Communism 336-348"/>
The government's inability to forestall Poland's economic decline led to waves of strikes across the country in April, May and August 1988. Under the reformist leadership of [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], the Soviet Union was becoming increasingly destabilized and unwilling to apply military and other pressure to prop up allied regimes in trouble. In the late 1980s, the government was forced to negotiate with Solidarity in the [[Polish Round Table Agreement|Polish Round Table Negotiations]]. The resulting [[Polish legislative election, 1989|Polish legislative election in 1989]] was a watershed event marking the [[Revolutions of 1989|fall of communism]] in Poland.
==Third Polish Republic (1989–today)== {{Further2|[[History of Poland (1989–present)]], [[Politics of Poland]]}} [[Image:Okragly Stol 1989.jpg|thumb|right|275 px|[[Polish Round Table Agreement|Round-table negotiations]] 1989]]
The [[Polish Round Table Agreement|"round-table" talks]] with the opposition began in February 1989. These talks produced the [[Polish Round Table Agreement|Round Table Agreement]] in April for [[Polish legislative election, 1989|partly open National Assembly elections]]. The failure of the communists at the polls produced a political crisis. The agreement called for a [[April Novelization|communist president]], and on July 19, the [[Contract Sejm|National Assembly]], with the support of a number of Solidarity deputies, elected General [[Wojciech Jaruzelski]] to that office. However, two attempts by the communists to form governments failed.
On August 19, President Jaruzelski asked journalist/Solidarity activist [[Tadeusz Mazowiecki]] to form a government; on September 12, the [[Sejm of the Republic of Poland|Sejm]] (national legislature) voted approval of Prime Minister Mazowiecki and his cabinet. For the first time in post-war history, Poland had a government led by noncommunists, setting a precedent to be soon followed by many other communist-ruled nations.<ref name="Poland under Communism ix"/>
In December 1989, the ''Sejm'' approved the government's reform program to transform the Polish economy rapidly from centrally planned to free-market, amended the [[Constitution of the People's Republic of Poland|constitution]] to eliminate references to the "leading role" of the Communist Party, and renamed the country the "Republic of Poland." The [[Polish United Workers' Party|Polish United Workers' (Communist) Party]] dissolved itself in January 1990, creating in its place a new party, [[Social Democracy of the Republic of Poland]].
[[File:Aleksander Kwasniewski i Lech Walesa,25lecie NSZZ.jpg|thumb|left|185px|President [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]] with [[Lech Wałęsa]] in 2005. Kwaśniewski defeated Wałęsa in the [[Polish presidential election, 1995|presidential election of 1995]]; he was one of the several "[[Democratic Left Alliance|post-communist]]" politicians elected to highest offices.]]
In October 1990, the constitution was amended to curtail the term of President Jaruzelski.
In the early 1990s, Poland made great progress towards achieving a fully democratic government and a market economy. In November 1990, Lech Wałęsa [[Polish presidential election, 1990|was elected president]] for a five-year term. In December Wałęsa became the first popularly elected [[President of Poland]].
Poland's [[Polish parliamentary election, 1991|first free parliamentary election]] was held in 1991. More than 100 parties participated, and no single party received more than 13% of the total vote. In [[Polish parliamentary election, 1993|1993 parliamentary election]] the "post-communist" [[Democratic Left Alliance]] (SLD) received the largest share of votes. In 1993 the Soviet [[Northern Group of Forces]] finally left Poland.
In November 1995, Poland held its [[Polish presidential election, 1995|second post-war free presidential election]]. SLD leader [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]] defeated Wałęsa by a narrow margin—51.7% to 48.3%.
In [[Polish parliamentary election, 1997|1997 parliamentary election]] two parties with roots in the Solidarity movement — [[Solidarity Electoral Action]] (AWS) and the [[Freedom Union (Poland)|Freedom Union]] (UW) — won 261 of the 460 seats in the ''Sejm'' and formed a coalition government. In April 1997, the new [[Constitution of Poland]] was finalized, and in July put into effect, replacing the previously used [[Small Constitution of 1992|amended]] [[Constitution of the People's Republic of Poland|communist statute]].
Poland joined [[NATO]] in 1999. Elements of the [[Polish Armed Forces]] have since participated in the [[Iraq War]] and the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan War]].
In the [[Polish presidential election, 2000|presidential election of 2000]], Aleksander Kwaśniewski, the incumbent former leader of the [[Democratic Left Alliance|SLD]], was re-elected in the first round of voting. After [[Polish parliamentary election, 2001|September 2001 parliamentary election]] SLD (a successor of the communist party) formed a coalition with the agrarian [[Polish People's Party]] (PSL) and the leftist [[Labour Union (Poland)|Labor Union]] (UP).
[[Image:Castle Square, Warsaw.jpg|thumb|right|325px|[[Castle Square, Warsaw|Castle Square]] in [[Warsaw]]'s rebuilt [[Warsaw Old Town|Old Town]]]]
Poland joined the [[European Union]] in May 2004. Both President Kwaśniewski and the government were vocal in their support for this cause. The only party decidedly opposed to EU entry was the populist right-wing [[League of Polish Families]] (LPR).
After the fall of communism the government policy of guaranteed full employment had ended and many large unprofitable state enterprises were closed or restructured. This and other economic woes of the transition period caused the unemployment to be at times as high as 20%. With the [[European Union|EU]] access, the gradual opening of West European labor markets to Polish workers, combined with the domestic economic growth, led to marked improvement in the employment situation (currently at around or above 10%) in Poland.<ref name="Unemployment rate Poland"/><ref name="Poland Unemployment rate"/><ref name="Eurostat unemployment"/>
[[Polish parliamentary election, 2005|September's 2005 parliamentary election]] was expected to produce a coalition of two center-right parties, PiS ([[Law and Justice]]) and PO ([[Civic Platform]]). During the bitter campaign PiS overtook PO, gaining 27% of votes cast and becoming the largest party in the Sejm, ahead of PO with 24%. In the [[Polish presidential election, 2005|presidential election in October]] the early favorite, [[Donald Tusk]], leader of the PO, was beaten 54% to 46% in the second round by the PiS candidate [[Lech Kaczyński]]. Coalition talks ensued simultaneously with the presidential elections, but negotiations ended up in a stalemate and the PO decided to go into opposition. PiS formed a minority government which relied on the support of smaller populist and agrarian parties ([[Self-Defense of the Republic of Poland|Samoobrona]], [[League of Polish Families|LPR]]) to govern. This became a formal coalition, but its deteriorating state made early parliamentary election necessary.
[[File:Sejm 2009 Komorowski.jpg|thumb|left|175 px|Current president [[Bronislaw Komorowski]] as the [[Marshal of the Sejm]]]]
In the [[Polish parliamentary election, 2007|2007 parliamentary election]], the Civic Platform was most successful (41.5%), ahead of Law and Justice (32%), and the government of Donald Tusk, the chairman of PO, was formed. PO governs in a parliamentary majority coalition with the smaller Polish People's Party (PSL).
In the current great [[Financial crisis of 2007–2010|worldwide economic downturn]], triggered and exemplified in particular by the [[Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008|2008 USA collapse and bailout of the banking system]], the Polish economy has weathered the crisis, in comparison with many European and other countries, relatively unscathed.<ref name="Poland Likely To Resist Global Slowdown"/><ref name="Economic Gloom in Europe Barely Touches Proud Poland"/> Worrisome signs, signalling upcoming difficulties are however present, and the [[European sovereign debt crisis]], unraveling some of Europe's economies, is expected to negatively affect also the economy of Poland, currently not a member of the [[eurozone]].<ref name="Get a move on"/><ref name="Poland Skirts Euro Zone"/>
The social price paid by the Poles for the implementation of [[economic liberalism|liberal free market economic policies]] has been the sharply more inequitable distribution of wealth and the associated impoverishment of large segments of the society.<ref name="Poles apart?"/> According to 2010 [[Eurostat]] data, 14% of Poles were "severely materially deprived", compared to the 8% EU average.<ref name="Eurostat poverty"/> This however represents the steepest of any European country drop in poverty rates over the past several years (it has taken place since Poland joined the EU).<ref name="Gazeta wyborcza poverty"/><ref name="Gazeta wyborcza common poverty"/>{{Ref label|h|h|none}}
Poland's president Lech Kaczyński and all aboard died in a [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|plane crash on April 10, 2010]] in western Russia, near [[Smolensk]]. President Kaczyński and other prominent Poles were on the way to the [[Katyn massacre]] anniversary commemoration.
[[File:European Union.svg|thumb|right|250px|Poles hope for historically unprecedented stability within the [[European Union]].<ref name="Viewpoint: Is Poland moving on from its turbulent past?"/> The [[Poland and the euro|introduction of the euro currency]] and its timing are difficult decisions, given the [[European sovereign debt crisis|economic crisis]] in the [[eurozone]].<ref name="Can Europe Be Saved?"/><ref name="Debt Rising in Europe"/>]]
In the second final round of the [[Polish presidential election, 2010|Polish presidential election]] on July 4, 2010, [[Bronisław Komorowski]], [[Acting President of Poland|Acting President]], [[Marshal of the Sejm]] and a Civic Platform politician, defeated [[Jarosław Kaczyński]] by 53% to 47%.
The [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|Smolensk tragedy]] brought into the open deep divisions within the Polish society and became a destabilizing factor in Poland's politics.<ref name="Poland, Lacking External Enemies, Turns on Itself"/><ref name="Division mars Poland's Smolensk plane crash anniversary"/><ref name="Divided Poles mark crash anniversary, rap Russia"/><ref name="Polish paper Rzeczpospolita fires editors over article on presidential crash "/>
Poland's relations with its European neighbors have been good or improving, with [[Belarus]] being a [[Human rights in Belarus|sore point]].<ref name="France Joins Poland and Germany on Wider Unity"/><ref name="Belarus Warns European Union Over Withdrawal of Envoys"/>{{Ref label|i|i|none}} The [[Eastern Partnership]] summit, hosted in September 2011 by Poland, the holder of the rotating [[Presidency of the Council of the European Union]], resulted in no agreement on near future expansion of the Union to include the several considered [[Eastern Europe]]an and [[Caucasus]] states, formerly [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet republics]]. The European Union membership for at least some of those states, including [[Ukraine]], has long been a goal of Polish diplomacy.<ref name="Move East Not on European Union's Agenda for the Moment"/> Poland has also been promoting NATO membership for Ukraine and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], a plan seen by Russia as threatening to its security<ref name="Russia:Border Conflicts Risk Nuclear War, Officer Says"/><ref name="Russia's military chief warns"/> and so far not supported by a majority of Ukrainian voters. For a number of years, Poland and Russia have disagreed on the planned [[NATO missile defense system]] in Europe, in which Poland has sought to be an active participant, and which Russia opposes.<ref name="Russia warns on missile defence deal with Nato and US"/>
The [[Polish parliamentary election, 2011|2011 parliamentary election]] results were generally an affirmation of the current distribution of political forces. The [[Civic Platform]] won over 39% of the votes, [[Law and Justice]] almost 30%, [[Palikot's Movement]] 10%, the [[Polish People's Party]] and the [[Democratic Left Alliance]] over 8% each. The new element was the successful debut of the left-of-center movement of [[Janusz Palikot]], a maverick politician, which resulted in decreased electoral appeal of the Democratic Left Alliance.<ref name="Poland election: In historic first, PM gets a second term"/>
[[File:2007 11 16 Zaprzysiężenie rządu Tuska (2).JPG|thumb|left|250px|Prime Minister [[Donald Tusk]]'s governing coalition [[Polish parliamentary election, 2011|received in October 2011]] a majority of parliamentary seats again]]
Poland's foreign minister, [[Radosław Sikorski]], delivered a speech on 28 November 2011 in [[Berlin]], in which he emphatically appealed to Germany and other European Union countries for closer economic and political integration and coordination, to be accomplished through a more powerful [[Institutions of the European Union|central government of the Union]]. Sikorski feels that decisive action and substantial reform, led by Germany, are necessary to prevent a collapse of the euro and subsequent destabilization and possible demise of the European Union. His remarks, directed primarily at the German audience, encountered hostile reception in Poland from Jarosław Kaczyński and his [[Law and Justice|conservative parliamentary opposition]], who accused the minister of betraying Poland's sovereignty and demanded his ouster and trial. Sikorski identified in his speech several areas important to Polish traditionalists, which, he said, should permanently remain within the domain of individual national governments.<ref name="Poland and the future of the European Union"/>
[[File:Warsaw6vb.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Warsaw high-rise district. The city's affluence and low unemployment rate attract newcomers.]]
As of 9 December 2011 UE summit in [[Brussels]], the British opposition prevented any changes to the [[Treaties of the European Union|EU Treaty]]. All the remaining UE governments, including the actively involved Polish delegation led by Prime Minister Tusk, indicated support for the new "fiscal compact" and greater coordination agreement, intended to impose financial discipline on member states and to cure the present instability in the [[eurozone]]. The agreed reforms will be implemented in the laws of individual states.<ref name="Statement by the Euro Area Heads"/><ref name="Europe's Debt Crisis Brings"/>
In January 2012, Poland's [[Public Prosecutor General|Prosecutor General]]'s office initiated investigative proceedings against [[Zbigniew Siemiątkowski]], the former [[Agencja Wywiadu|Polish intelligence]] chief. Siemiątkowski is charged with facilitating the alleged [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] [[Black site|detention operation in Poland]], where foreign suspects may have been tortured in the context of the [[War on Terror]]. The alleged [[Constitution of Poland|constitutional]] and [[international law]] [[war crime|trespasses]] took place when [[Leszek Miller]], presently member of [[Sejm of the Republic of Poland|parliament]] and leader of the [[Democratic Left Alliance]], was Prime Minister (2001-2004), and he may also be subjected to future [[State Tribunal of the Republic of Poland|legal action]].<ref name="Poland ex-spy boss 'charged over alleged CIA secret prison'"/><ref name="Polish Ex-Official Charged With Aiding C.I.A."/><ref name="Więzienia CIA w Polsce"/> [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]], the President of Poland at that time, acknowledged knowing about and consenting to (together with the Prime Minister) the secret "CIA prisons".<ref name="Kwaśniewski w szarej strefie więzień CIA"/>
During the [[Patriarch of Moscow and all the Rus'|Russian Patriarch]]'s visit to Poland on August 16–19, 2012, [[Kirill I of Moscow|Kirill I]], Primate of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] and Archbishop [[Józef Michalik]], President of the [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] [[Polish Episcopal Conference|Conference of Polish Bishops]], signed a historic Polish-Russian church message on reconciliation and mutual forgiveness.<ref name="Russian Orthodox leader to visit Poland, sign reconciliation statement"/><ref name="Russian Patriarch Kirill makes historic visit to Poland"/><ref name="Churches in Polish-Russian appeal for friendly ties"/>

== Notes == <div class="references-small">
''a.''{{Note label|a|a|none}}Piłsudski's family roots in the [[Polonization|Polonized]] gentry of the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]] and the resulting point of view (seeing himself and people like him as legitimate Lithuanians) put him in conflict with the [[Lithuanian National Revival|modern Lithuanian]] nationalists (who in Piłsudski's lifetime redefined the scope of the "Lithuanian" connotation), by extension with other nationalists, and also with the [[National Democracy|Polish modern nationalist movement]].<ref name="Snyder 40-41, 64-65, 68-69"/>
''b.''{{Note label|b|b|none}}The Polish ruling elites considered the Soviets in some ways more threatening then the [[Nazi Germany|Nazis]]. The outbreak of the war followed the periods of [[Stalinism|Stalinist]] terror.<ref name="Heart 145"/>
[[Image:Poland & The New Baltic States.jpg|thumb|225px|right|Poland and the [[Baltic states|Baltic areas]] after the treaties of [[Treaty of Versailles|Versailles]] and [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk|Brest-Litovsk]] and before the [[Peace of Riga]]]]
''c.''{{Note label|c|c|none}}An establishment of Poland restricted to "minimal size", according to ethnographic boundaries (such as the ones shown on this 1920 map, or the lands common to both prewar Poland and postwar Poland),<ref name="Overy 236 map"/> was recommended by [[Ivan Maisky]] to [[Vyacheslav Molotov]] in early 1944, because of what Maisky saw as Poland's historically unfriendly disposition toward Russia and the Soviet Union. [[Joseph Stalin]] opted for a larger version, allowing a "swap" (territorial compensation for Poland), which involved the [[Kresy|eastern lands]] gained by Poland at the [[Peace of Riga]] of 1921 and now lost, and [[Recovered Territories|eastern Germany]] conquered form the Nazis in 1945.<ref name="Poland under Communism 1-3"/> Other territorial and ethnic scenarios were also possible, generally with outcomes less favorable to Poland than its present form.<ref name="Norman Davies 1939"/>
''d.''{{Note label|d|d|none}}Timothy Snyder spoke of about 100,000 Jews killed by Poles during the Nazi occupation, majority probably by members of the [[collaborationism|collaborationist]] [[Blue Police]].<ref name="Polacy wobec Holocaustu"/> This number would have likely been many times higher had Poland entered into an alliance with Germany in 1939, as advocated by some Polish post-war and post-1989 historians and others.
''e.''{{Note label|e|e|none}}Some may have had falsely claimed the [[Jewish identity]] hoping for permissions to emigrate. The communist authorities, pursuing the concept of Poland of single ethnicity (in accordance with the recent border changes and expulsions),<ref name="Buszko 410"/><ref name="Snyder 89"/> were allowing the Jews to leave the country.<ref name="Poland under Communism 23"/>
''f.''{{Note label|f|f|none}}A [[Communist Party of Poland]] had existed in the past, but was eliminated in [[Great Purge|Stalin's purges]] in 1938.<ref name="Poland under Communism 18"/>
''g.''{{Note label|g|g|none}}The Soviet leadership, which had previously ordered the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956|Hungarian Revolution]] and the [[Prague Spring]] crushed, now became worried about the demoralization of the Polish army, a crucial [[Warsaw Pact]] component, because of it being used against Polish workers. They withdrew their support for Gomułka, who insisted on the use of force, and the Polish [[politburo]] ousted him and his close associates.<ref name="Poland under Communism 187, 196"/>
''h.''{{Note label|h|h|none}}The shrinking poverty sphere has been possible because of the reduced unemployment and the influx of the European Union funds. Over two million Poles however have left the country to work abroad. According to some Polish academic researchers, the Eurostat data, based on the information collected by [[Central Statistical Office (Poland)|Central Statistical Office]] of Poland, does not fully reflect the scope of poverty in Poland.<ref name="Gazeta wyborcza poverty"/> Poverty is becoming increasingly permanent in post-industrial urban areas and has highest levels among children. The two articles quoted agree on the greatest poverty rate reduction of any European country, both invoke Eurostat, but give widely divergent numerical figures.<ref name="Gazeta wyborcza common poverty"/>
''i.''{{Note label|i|i|none}}Following the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|presidential election]] of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] and the subsequent persecution of [[Yulia Tymoshenko]], Poland's and European Union's relations with [[Ukraine]] have also entered a period of difficulty.<ref>Marcin Wojciechowski, ''Ukraina odpływa ku Rosji'' (Ukraine sails away toward Russia), Gazeta Wyborcza, 2012-05-12</ref>
